- Welcome to conversations with leaders.
My name is Miriam McLemore,
and I'm an enterprise strategist with AWS.

I am thrilled today to
have some time to speak

with Igor Tsyganskiy, who
is the CTO of Bridgewater.
Welcome to the program Igor.
- Great to be here.
- Igor let's jump in.
Could you give us a snapshot
of Bridgewater and your role there?

- Bridgewater is the largest
hedge fund in the world.
We manage more than $150 billion
for institutions around the world.

Some of them are pension
funds, endowment funds,

some wealth funds, as well as
governmental organizations.
As an organization,

we think about timeless
and universals rules

that drive monetary
flows around the world.
We then export those rules into code
and into our software systems
that then, while supervised by us,
invest money into most of the markets
in almost every country around the world.
- Compared to most financial institutions,

Bridgewater has been
often an early adopter
of new technologies.
Can you tell us a little bit

about your approach to
technology adoption?

- We always have to be
on the edge of technology
since the world is always changing,
and the rules about how the world works
get more and more complex.

Having more compute power
in a more flexible way

is almost required for us to
continue running our business.

So about 10 years ago,
we were early adopters.

We partnered with AWS and
we were early adopters
of using AWS to provide us
with mission critical elastic compute

to calculate our timeless
and universal rules.
That created a huge wave
of innovation inside of Bridgewater
that allowed us to scale our understanding

of what's going on by
more than a thousand X
in the last five years.

We believe that that
created and allowed us
to continue being in the business
and to continue innovating.

- Your use particularly
of cloud technology
is an interesting story.

Can you share a little
bit about that as well?

- We partnered with AWS
about six years ago.
Some of the challenges that we were facing
is our ability as I've mentioned before
our ability to grow data centers
was pretty impaired compared to
the need that the business had
for both elastic and flexible compute.

We also needed to respond
to ever changing challenges
of cyber risk that are now a lot greater
than they were five or six years ago.

I believe that we've had
an amazing relationship
where both of our companies
had a chance of growing up together,
and we helped AWS learn what it means

to run mission critical
applications and workloads,
and AWS actually provided us all the scale
that we needed in the world.

It's been an amazing
relationship in that way.

- So in these unprecedented
times that we're all living in,
Bridgewater was able to continue
to serve its customers without disruption.
Was that based on this technology adoption
that you had made?

- We've shifted to working
from home 18 to 24 months ago,

and have been working
without any interruptions,
essentially virtually for all that time.
We were also able to shift
to supporting our customers virtually
using AWS without interruptions.
And that is just amazing.

Not only were we faced
with the needs of COVID,
but also we were faced

with the fact that markets
had been most volatile
over the last 18 months or so.
And our increase in compute demand

have by and large grown
by about three X at times,
and at peak has grown about 10 X.
That is our unprecedented need
for elastic compute that even 10 years ago
we were not able to satisfy,
and only via our partnership with AWS
were we able to do this.

And this is one of the reasons
I'm doing this interview

is to highlight how grateful
we are for the partnership,
and the work that we've done together
over this period of time.
- And so compute for obvious reasons then
is absolutely critical, right?
- Absolutely, compute is most critical.
It's one of the most important elements

to enable Bridgewater
operating successfully
on an ongoing basis,
especially when the markets are volatile.

And when the world is
changing so much our ability

to compute these timeless
and universal rules
is of utmost importance.
- And you've described before,

I've heard you talk about
the importance of partnership
and kind of how you define that.
Can you share a little bit
about your thoughts on partnering?

- Listen, effective
partnering is interdependence
on the parties working together.
Not everything can always go great.
And supporting each other

in the time of need is what
partnership is all about.
Partnership is in Bridgewater's DNA.

We don't look at our
customers as customers.
We look at them as partners.

We're there to support
them in the time of need.

And we don't look at
our vendors as vendors.
We look at them as partners.

We support them when
they need our support,
and we believe they support us,

the best vendors support
us when we need support.

And that has come true
absolutely in the last 18 months

where we have gotten all
the support that we needed

from AWS to provide us with
stable, continuous compute,

and availability at the
most critical times.
- Tell us about how you make
technology investment decisions.

- For Bridgewater, making
technology investment decisions,
first and foremost means to understand
what business impact one wants to achieve.

One of the things that
I've done is assemble

technology advisory
committee here at Bridgewater
that consists of some of the luminaries

in computer industry, as
well as cybersecurity:
Craig Mundie, Keith Alexander,
Adam Bosworth, and some others.
First, we fully deeply go for the process

of understanding of what
business impact we want.

And then we evaluate pretty
much all the technologies,

whether they're external, or
we evaluate the opportunity
to build the technology internally
in order to satisfy those business needs.
Having the wisdom and the discussion

with the technology advisory
board helps me figure out

which road to take and which
partners to go and choose.
And it's for that collaborative process
together with the employees

we decide on how to choose
our next investments.

Sometimes the technology
is differentiating
and it's very important,
but when it comes down to the fact

that multiple companies might
have similar technology,
our ability to partner with a company
becomes very, very important.
And figuring out who we're gonna bet on

is an important choice and
becomes almost paramount
towards making big technology bets.
- Yeah, no, I love that,

and the outside in and the
inside out view that you have.

Any advice Igor that you would
have to technology leaders
or business leaders looking to adopt cloud
and transforming their business?
- Well, I would tell them
to let go of their fear and worries

and just take the plunge,
move to the cloud.

It's one of the best things
that we've done at Bridgewater

and every single company
should consider doing the same.
There are many reasons one should worry
about moving to the cloud,
but there are even so many more reasons
on why one should be in the cloud.
The notion of elastic compute.

The notion of ever changing
needs of cyber security

is something one cannot
just do by themselves.

Companies in the current
environment are hopeless
in trying to figure out on how to move
and evolve without tight partnerships
with companies like Amazon.
I strongly suggest for everyone
to consider moving to the cloud,
to make their decisions,

to first think about on
why they should do it
and think about how can they solve
the problems that they have

versus focusing on the
problems that they have
and essentially saying,

well we cannot do it because
of the problems that we have.
Talent of the future is not willing

to work in environments
that are legacy and old,

which creates in itself a
self-fulfilling prophecy
of being able to move forward
and keep up with computing evolution.

- Igor, thank you so much
for that, for your insights,
for your time, and for your partnership.
We so much appreciate you and Bridgewater.
